author: A_Brickset_user
review: I had a lot of fun with this before my "Destruction Age" (My mother got tired of LEGOs invading the house, and told me to take all but one or two things of my choice apart, then start over and build new things. I sadly misunderstood, and not only took the structures apart, but most of my minifigs, and wheels from tires also. My Unitron, and Ice Planet figures were never seen again. There torsos anyway, and that is what counts. I quickly re-built as much as I could.) Plenty of good parts and pieces include the grey bird, and alligator, camping equipment and tools, lots of good car pieces, and a good car if you keep it together, as well as pretty good mountain scene. One of the last sets released before the Junior Era began, and a very good one.

author: Elle82
title: Good addition to any collection
review: What stands out with this set, is the vehicle has suspension! allowing the wheels to rock from side to side, helps when you are going over a bridge made of ladders. Other than that, its basic, but add it to another adventure type set!

author: hustla187
title: Sweet Truck
review: The thing that really gets people is the truck. The truck is nicely built and fun to play with. The suspension is crazy on this truck and now you don't see much of the suspension axles. The bridge is nice too, but I got to give credit to Lego for making a good 4 wide car. This set should be rereleased because it's so good.

author: ledaKat
title: This Set Brightens My Day
review:
No matter how tough my day can get, when I come home and look at that poor hiker who became dinner for a hungry croc, I cannot help but laugh.  What a treasure that tiny detail is.

This set is medium to small, but every piece is important and gives it the charm that all sets from the early 90s possess. The truck is just cool. Love the tire suspension, the spare tire and the blue tinted sun roof. I really appreciate the box and instruction artwork of these older sets. They show exactly what the set is, no trick photography, no unnatural poses. What you see is what you get. Some of the later models tend to over dramatize the set by the cover artwork and lead you to believe it is a lot more sophisticated than it actually is. Can be a little disapointing especially for younger children who don't understand marketing tools.

If you have some more sets with rocks and landscape scene this would fit in really nicely and enhance it even more. I plan to get some more, I think it would work well with Rocky River Retreat.

Pros:
truck and cable
crocodile and skeleton remains
bridge
minifig's green outfit is nice

Cons:
none

author: ngyr
title: Good times
review:
I'm 13 right now but my brother is from 1990. When I was little, it was our favourite set and only it wasn't taken apart to build something else. 

It is just great. Good parts - crocodile, suspension, whole back of the track.

The only thing I don't like in this set is using a juniorized BURP instead of normal bricks. This is why building experience is 3 here, not 4.

author: fgee
title: Most funny riding experience ever
review:
Thanks to the suspension, this is the car with the most funny riding experience of my collection. I love riding it over all and everything, including through my bed and such - it runs smoothly, without loosing road contact. Very clever.

 

In addition, it is made mostly of standard bricks rather than special-shaped pieces. This makes it one of the most valuable car sets in that era of "quick and dirty built" cars from late nineties. Only backside is the BURP.

author: KLOKRIECHER
title: LEGO Town (Leisure) - Amazon Crossing Review
review:
This is a fun set to have and it's fun to play with as well.

Box/Instructions

The instruction has 16 pages and there're no mistakes in it.

Parts

This set has a lot of great and useful pieces for future MOC's (My own creations) and/or brickfilms for sure.

Minifigures

The figure looks very cool, too. The driver has a red cap, a green vest, a white shirt, green pants and black shades on his face.

The build

The build was very nice and easy and we also don't need to worry about stickers as well.

The completed model

[img]http://www.klokriecher.de/gallery_pics/l/6490-1.jpg[/img]


This set is very cool. We get a nice jeep and a bridge. We also get an alligator. The brown pieces which LEGO uses for the bridge can be adjusted and it's big enough for the truck to pass it. The vehicle itself has a nice suspension mechanism and on the front we get a cable which you can pull out. The ceiling and the doors on each side can be opened very easily as well. On the back of the truck you can see an antenna which can be adjusted as well and there's also a place where you can put an extra tyre which comes with this set. On the top we'll find a gun and a pickaxe. What I thought was very cool is that LEGO has added a skull and some bones with this set.

Summary

All in all this set is an great set and I would HIGHLY recommend you to get this. You can find this set on eBay, BrickLink and Amazon for sure. Here is the link where you can check out the full gallery I made for this set on my website: http://www.klokriecher.de

Videos I made of this set:

Stopmotion 1

Stopmotion 2

Stopmotion 3

Stopmotion 4

Review

author: kbcakir
title: My Childhood Dream
review:
I could not get this set when I was a kid because I was too late to buy it from TRU or other local markets. I met this awesome  set from the catalogs. I hardly remember getting my first proper Lego set in 1997 or 1998, this was on the catalogs but I couldn't be able to find it anywhere. I always dreamed about the possibilities of adventures , it will offer. I remember myself feeling amazed by how designers added a gun to the inventory to poor minifig defend himself against cruel croc or any other villains in desert.Gun in a town set was not usual. After many years of dreaming and 5-6 years of dark age I met bricklink and finally got this in a sealed box. I opened it without hesitating I still keep its box in the glove compartment of my car as a lucky charm.

Box/Instructions

Box look primitive when compared to current ones but present what you will get objectively.

 

Parts

With today's mind parts are not really impressive but with a very low part count it turns out a big set. You get aan awesome car a threatening croc and some rocks to perform your offroad skills.The starring part of the set is suspension thingy for sure. I wish they produce a modern version of it. 

 

Minifigures

Yeah I admit he is not impressive today but, when I was a child this head with ray-ban style glasses was one of the coolest heads (I remember myself using it even for castle figures) and torso captures camel trophy soul very well indeed.

The build

The build is not enjoyable like today's Camper van or Parisian restaurant but getting cliffs a 4x4 and a wild beast for just 15 dollars wow I can't think about for today

 

The completed model

Just try to drive that little jeep across, you will understand what I mean you can feel it rolls!

Overall opinion

I really wish some themes like outback and divers. I accept today lego sets are more detailed and enjoyable but they sometimes dedicate you how you live your adventures. But with these realistic sets, you can be either bad or good guy and spend your day by commiting or preventing crime, 90's has atmosphere like a GTA game, they did not tell you what to do or how you live. This set reminds me what I really miss about lego, maybe someday they will remember and with today's possibilities we will enjoy the best lego adventure ever.

author: TheK79_selbst
title: farewell with a scull head
review:
This set was the last of the classic “Town” series (it's 7+ for little over 100 pieces!), being replaced in 1997 by the new Juniorised series later called “City”. And looking into the details, it looks like the designers wanted to say “farewell” with it…

The bridge is build like a diorama with the stones only making a thin "wall" in the background. And the setting is straight from the end of the world… a wobbly bridge over dangerous animals and the remains of some not so fortune traveller. It looks, as if he's fleeing the dying town…

But there is also an interesting technical aspect. For the first time ever, Lego used all ten non-transparent colours existing back then in a single set:

  • black for winch, Antenna, tires, pan and some more
  • light grey for the stones
  • white for the bones
  • red for the cap and the fire extinguisher
  • blue for the water
  • yellow for most of the car
  • green for the crocodile and the bush
  • brown for the bridge and the backpack
  • dark grey for hammer and rifle
  • and for the first time ever a brick appeared in “tan”: the sand on both sided of the river.

Saying “farewell” to “Town” in the most colourful way ever with the darkest setting ever…

author: TopFloorBricks
title: Amaz(on)ing!
review:
Overview

You tend to find on Brickset that rating correlates positively with set size/price and whilst this is not the largest set, I genuinely think this is one of the best sets LEGO have ever done. There are so many elements that make it so superb and I shall do my best in this review to narrate them to you.

The Build

The instructions tell you to build the bridge scene first, consisting of three plates to show the water and riverbanks, light grey rocks that provide the desolate looking backdrop to the scene and the eponymous wooden crossing which looks so rickety you're just asking for trouble crossing here, crocodile or no crocodile. The tan plates, rocky features and the fact the only bit of foliage is the bush really makes the scene look barren, like a location from Breaking Bad. Town sets can sometimes feel a little 'safe'. Even when there are police chasing a criminal it tends to be done in a cartoonish way, whereas this set looks gritty and dangerous which makes it really stand out. Outback was a really cool subtheme as it added that sense of adventure to real life, believable sets.

The bridge is an inspired construction. It utilises the ladder pieces in an innovative way, surely what LEGO is all about. It also manages to balance looking precarious yet being structurally sound. Any journey across will be perilous as the ladders naturally wobble around yet they don't actually come apart. Thoroughly well designed and a perfect match for many LEGO vehicles, not least of all the truck.

The yellow colour may be arbitrary but just about everything else about the truck is just. It builds up in a detailed way from a large base and manages to be large without looking large. It's astonishing how much room there is at the back. So much room for (activities) equipment.  I love the suspension here as well. In some vehicles those pieces can seem redundant but here they dovetail so nicely with the wooden bridge.

The Features

Let's start with the minifigure. Our buddy is pretty standard, with an all green affair complemented by a red cap. Nothing flashy but a perfect match for this set. Can't be wearing anything too smart as chances are he'll have to get his hands dirty at some point! I like the choice of sunglasses face too, adds to the impression of dry, scorching heat and makes him look more like he can tough it out than a plain face.

He gets a lot of kit to help him out too, with a fire extinguisher, pickaxe, rucksack, frying pan and rifle. The latter is rare in a Town set and, as a previous reviewer pointed out, a first. Again, this adds to the serious nature of the set. There is also a camera piece but this is attached to the rear aerial. Not sure what it's doing there to be honest and actually I'm not keen on the aerial part as it snaps off quite easily, not ideal when the truck is clearly meant to be very robust. There is ample room to store the rucksack and camera in the back of the truck and you could achieve the aerial effect by sticking a lever on the roof. I'm not convinced with the spare tyre be stored in the back either. I feel this could be stored on a 4488 piece attached to the back of the truck which would be both functional and look good. You would of course have to get rid of the aerial to make room. I feel that a 30150 piece would look good in the back, though I'm not sure it had come into circulation at the time. You may have to do some slight design alterations to fit in in too. Nevertheless, the rucksack, camera and frying pan can easily fit loose in the back and is a better use of the space than a spare tyre.

The main feature of the truck is the winch at the front. They have built it efficiently, only using a grey pole with no handle to crank. Although this makes it more fiddly to use I like it as it adds to the rough and ready nature of the vehicle. The clip means that the winch fits securely to the bridge and can also be used in other settings.

The bones, skull and bird all contribute nicely to the deserty bleakness of the scene and our scaly friend can interact with said bones.

The Play

For such a small set with only one minifigure there is so much playability here. The classic is of course or intrepid adventurer having to winch his truck across the perilous bridge while the dangerous croc lurks in the river. The image of him precariously clambering over to fix the winch in place is excellent. The winch's versatility also would allow the truck to pull a second vehicle over the bridge if it gets struck, as long as it had something for the winch to attach too. I normally paired it with 6514 as that looks hardy enough to be in the outback but not powerful enough to cross that bridge. There is also enough space for a small camp to be set up on the riverbank. Our buddy can park up his truck for the night and set up a cookfire and of course he has a fire extinguisher on hand if it goes wrong!

Summary

All in all, an absolute belter of a set. Builds good, looks good and plays good all without being mega expensive. The only real problem with it is the name! Amazon Crossing doesn't work here, as I picture jungles and swamps when I imagine the Amazon. I think this set is much more in keeping with either the American South West or, as the subtheme title suggests, central Australia. Still, when the worst thing about a set is its name, you know its a winner.
